awd_titl_txt: CPS: TTP Option: Medium: Collaborative Research: Low-Cost, High-Throughput, Cyber-Physical Synthesis of Encrypted DNA
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will research a new process for manufacturing large-scale libraries of synthetic DNA oligonucleotides, which are widely used in genomics research and are now being considered as a medium for long-term archival data storage. The current price for synthesizing DNA using microarray technology is 10 cents per base, equivalent to about $3,500 per Megabyte of storage.  This project attempts to reduce the cost of DNA synthesis from 10 cents to around 0.007 cents per base using computer-controlled, high-throughput sorting. The DNA synthesis method will also include automatic data encryption. While the development of conventional digital data storage technologies (e.g., hard disk, flash memory) preceded the integration of encryption, pursuing encryption as part of the DNA synthesis process ensures that future DNA-based archival storage modalities will be robustly protected from tampering. 
 
The project builds on systems engineering principles and the foundations of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS). DNA will be synthesized on a laser-light activated microtransponder chip (p-Chip) that transmits a unique ID by radio frequency (RF) or optical signaling, and can be used as a solid-phase support for DNA synthesis. Of particular importance is the design of a high-throughput microfluidic sorter/manifold, that can rapidly sort p-Chips in real-time, delivering them to reservoirs which apply the appropriate DNA chemistry to synthesize and append the next oligonucleotide to the sequence being grown on each p-Chip.  Three 12-inch silicon production wafers carry enough p-Chips to synthesize a library of 5,000,000 unique DNA sequences, or a genome of 300,000,000 base pairs. p-Chips are chemically inert, compatible with DNA synthesis, and dense enough to allow high-speed mechanical separation. The intellectual significance of the work involves: (1) investigation of fluid modeling algorithms for p-Chips flowing through the high-speed microfluidic p-Chip sorter/manifold, including the needed corrections to the computational fluid flow models produced by commercial software, (2) investigation of a co-design process for fluidic CPS and its application to the creation of a sorter/manifold for current-generation (500 x 500 x 100 cubic micrometers) and next-generation (50 x 50 x 100 cubic micrometers) p-Chips, (3) real time software and/or Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) control for the sorter/manifold to enable ultra-high throughput DNA synthesis, (4) support for encrypted DNA synthesis, and (5) integration of the sorter/manifold and control mechanism into a commercial DNA synthesizer.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the design of a highly efficient manufacturing system for synthetic DNA and other similar biomolecules. The basic premise is to synthesize DNA onto micrometer-scale semiconductor chips whose surfaces have been coated with a biocompatible polymer. The synthesizer transports semiconductor chips between four reservoirs, each of which is capable of adding one of the four DNA bases (adenine [A], cytosine [C], guanine [G], or thymine [T]) to the current strand of DNA being grown on each chip. 

 The intellectual merit of the project encompassed the design of the machine itself, which integrated a variety of microfluidic components, solenoid valves, laser and camera-tracking systems, and a control software program that was implemented on a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA). A significant effort was undertaken to understand the physics of semiconductor chips suspended in liquid flowing through microfluidic channels; unlike, for example, living cells, semiconductor chips are square/cubic, rather than round/spherical, are rigid, rather than deformable, and are non-neutrally buoyant. Modeling this behavior necessitated the investigation of novel computational fluid dynamics simulations, which provided insight into the hydrodynamic and adhesion forces that act on rigid semiconductor chips. This informed the development of highly specialized computer vision algorithms that detect and track semiconductor chips flowing through microfluidic channels, including the ability to detect translation, rotation, and tumbling.  The project team successful completed a prototype of a real-time sorting module that is capable of identifying, detecting, and controlling the movement of semiconductor chips as needed to facilitate synthetic DNA synthesis. The project also investigated security implications of existing DNA synthesis technologies, and demonstrated that existing synthesizers are not secure: an adversary with a consumer-grade microphone can record the sounds made by a DNA synthesizer and determine precisely what sequence of DNA had been synthesized during the recording period. 

 The broader impacts of the project were to reduce the cost of DNA synthesis from approximately 10 cents per base at the project’s incept, to as low as 0.007 cents per base upon translation to practice. The project also provided training opportunities for multiple PhD students and undergraduates at the University of California, Riverside, and the University of California, Irvine. The development of a high-throughput, inexpensive DNA synthesizer will help to aid advancement in research in synthetic biology and further foment DNA as a medium for long-term digital data storage.
